newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia dlr support survives, but bears stubborn.
newsitem.headline: Australia dlr support survives, but bears stubborn.

text.p: Australian dollar support survived another session of offshore pressure Wednesday in a struggle to establish exactly where its floor lay after Friday's rate cut.
On the bid side today were local corporates, and some of the local banks along with options-related demand which had held the line at US$0.7635 since Friday's slide from US$0.7770.

On the offer were a who's who of U.S. investment banks who had been aggressive sellers since the dollar's yield advantage disappeared. Traders suspected they were out both to trigger a stop-loss rout and, more worrying for bulls in the longer run, to lighten their portfolio exposure to the currency.
By 5.00 pm (0700 GMT) the local dollar was keeping its chin up at US$0.7658/63 having dipped as low as US$0.7634 during the day after finishing Tuesday at US$0.7650/55 here.

Further chart support was put at US$0.7620 and 76 cents while bears had their sights on the 1997 low of US$0.7550 hit in February. A break would see it to 15-month lows and risk a return to the 73 cent trough from January last year.

On the topside, resistance at US$0.7675 had established itself as tough over the last couple of days, but analysts felt the market was short enough overall to allow a squeeze to the US$0.7710/20 area short term.
But the dollar would have to recover the US$0.7770 level held before the Reserve Bank's easing, to counter the present bearish trend.

Traders felt this a tall order given Australian money market rates out to two-years had already fallen below those in the U.S. and looked likely to move further in the US$'s favour given the pace of U.S. economic growth.

The latest strength came Tuesday when consumer sentiment data for May showed a rousing 8.6 point jump to a 28-year high of 127.1. If the Fed did hike it would take official U.S. rates above Australian levels for the first in more than a decade.
On the crosses the local currency was loitering at 88.90/00 yen from 88.70/80 late here Tuesday.
Dealers said there was an undercurrent of concern about impending maturities of dual currency samurai bonds, made worse by mistaken press reports of the amount involved.

One Japanese newspaper said bonds worth as much as 90 billion Australian dollars were coming due -- a wild figure which would have come close to half of the country's entire national debt. This was later corrected to 90 billion yen, or a much more manageable A$810 million, but the brief scare served as a taste of things to come later this year.

From October onwards a flood of yen/A$ samurais do mature and if Japanese investors chose not to roll these over or re-invest the money into other A$ assets, the currency could come under pressure against the yen, said dealers.
In trade weighted terms the dollar was steady at 58.3.
On the domestic front, economic data Thursday might offer a little direction although the RBA had rendered them largely irrelevant by cutting rates when it did.
Business inventories for the March quarter will add another piece to the GDP jigsaw. Forecasts are for a 0.5 percent rise following a larger than expected 1.2 percent gain in Q4.
Since it is the size of the change that matters with stocks, such a gain would imply a small detraction from growth in the quarter.

Also out Thursday is the balance of goods and services for April, which has partly replaced the old monthly current account series. Analysts are looking for a surplus of around A$100 million after a A$103 million deficit in March.
More important will be quarterly balance of payments data Friday which will provide the first current account details for the March quarter and a contribution of exports to GDP.
